Chase Products Co. manufactures an extensive list                                      (955) of aerosol type products. Chase Products Co.
 uses an aerosol propellant storage system to contain
their A31 (100%isobutane); A46 (85%isobutane/15% propane; and A80 (60%propane/40%n-butane) 
gases which are used as the primary propellants
in their aerosol products. The system consists of 
three on-site USTs each having a maximum storage
capacity of 18,000 gallons and one 30,000-gallon 
railcar.  The USTs and railcar are connected to a 
series of pumps and conveyance pipes, which 
ultimately transfer the propellants to 16-ounce  (12. 25oz net) product cans.  The propellant storage  and conveyance system utilizes various process
controls including vents, pressure relief valves,                
manual shut offs, interlocks, excess flow devices
and propellant detectors and alarms as a means of 
preventing, and when appropriate, mitigating 
accidental releases.  Personnel follow standard 
operating procedures for the system operation. In
addition, an operations and maintenance program is 
 followed for the purpose of safety and effectively
operating the propellant storage system.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Introduction

This report was developed in accordance with USEPA 40 CFR Part 68 guidance on Risk Management Programs and serves as a Risk Management Plan (RMP) to be used by Chase Products Company.  The information presented in the RMP is derived from data obtained in Chase Products Company?s Emergency Response Contingency Plan and interviews with operations personnel.

Chase Products Co. manufactures an extensive list of aerosol type products.  Some examples of these products include personal hygiene (i.e., spray detergents, hair spray, etc.) and residential use (i.e., glass cleaner, insecticides and spray paints).  Chase Products Co. uses an aerosol propellant storage system to contain their A31 (100% isobutane); A46 (85%isobutane/15% propane); and A80 (60% propane/40% n-butane) gases which are used as the primary propellants in their aerosol products.  The system consists of three on-site USTs each having a maximum storage capacity of 18,000 gallons and one 30,000-gallon rail car.  The USTs and railcar are connected to a series of pumps and conveyance pipes, which ultimately transfer the propellants to 16-ounce (12.25 oz net) product cans.  Because Chase Products Co.?s aerosol propellant storage system is subject to OSHA PSM standards, the system falls under Program 3 requirements according to EPS?s Risk Management Program.  No additional RMP processes were identified at the site.

Stationary Source Description

This RMP report details the operations associated with the propellant storage system used in the manufacturing of aerosol type products.  The following stationary sources of propane, n-butane and isobutane within the storage system include:

    
? USTs & Railcar ? the three USTs each have an operating capacity of 18,000 gallons.  The railcar has an operating capacity of 30,000 gallons.  The USTs and railcar are connected to a series of pumps and above ground pipes for transfer into the facility?s aerosol can production line.  The USTs and

railcar are considered to be a stationary source because of the potential to leak the entire amount of their contents, resulting in a subsequent vapor cloud explosion.

? Propellant System Control Valve ? A31, A46 and A80 propellants pass through control valves located overtop of the USTs containing these propellants.  These valves may be manually operated to isolate sections of the propellant distribution system.  An exterior valve is considered a stationary source since a leak may develop around the valve stem packing, which may produce a vapor cloud that could potentially ignite and travel offsite.
    



Executive Summary

Chase Products Company is committed to worker and public safety in the operation of our facility.  This commitment to safety is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training programs and administrative controls in our process.  
Chase Products Co. utilizes the elements of a process safety management (PSM) program to ensure that our propellant storage system is operated in the safest manner achievable.

Chase Products Co. manufacturers an extensive list of aerosol type products.  Some examples of these products include personal hygiene (i.e., spray deodorants, hair spray, etc.) and residential use (i.e., glass cleaner, insecticides and spray paints). Chase Products Co. uses an aerosol propellant storage system to contain their A31 (100%isobutane); A46 (85% isobutane/15% propellant); and A80 (60% propane/40% n-butane) gases which are used as the primary propellants in their aerosol products.  The system consists of three on-site USTs each having a maximum storage capacity of 18,000 gallons and one 30,000-gallon railcar. The USTs and railcar are connected to a series of pumps and conveyance pipes, which ultimately transfer the propellants to 16-ounce (12.25 oz net) product cans.  Because Chase Products Co.?s aerosol propellant storage system is subject OSHA PSM standards, the system falls under Program 3

requirements according to EPA?s Risk Management Program.  No additional RMP processes were identified at the site.
                                            

The process at the facility that is regulated by the RMP is also OSHA?s PSM standard.  Chase Products Co.?s PSM program includes detailed process safety information.  Chase Products Co. conducts process hazards analyses to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage the hazards.  Operations at the facility are conducted according to standard operating procedures and employees are trained on the procedures.  Chase Products Co. ensures mechanical integrity of its propellant storage system by conducting routine daily inspections and promptly correcting identified deficiencies.  Chase Products Co.?s flammable substance release prevention programs include temperature sensors and pressure gauges located along the piping network to the USTs containing the flammable propellants.  In addition, flammable gas release detection sensors are located in the union pump area adjacent to the UST system.  The sensors will activate an alarm light inside the operations building when the gas concentration reaches 20% of the lower explosive limit (LEL) in the union pump area.  At 40% of the LEL, an audio alarm sounds and complete pump shutdown is initiated.  The flammable gas detection sensors are currently not located in the area of the USTs and railcar.

Chase Products Co. had no accidental releases of flammable gases in the past five years that resulted in onsite or offsite injuries or deaths, onsite property damage or offsite environmental damage.
                                            
Chase Products Co. maintains a written emergency response contingency plan that satisfies the requirements for contingency planning and/or notification procedures under the Illinois Toxic Substances Disclouser to Employees Act, OSHA Hazard Communication Rule and Illinois Chemical Safety Act.  The plan?s purpose is to establish emergency and notification procedures to be fol

lowed in the event of chemical, environmental or other emergencies.  Personnel are trained as emergency coordinators and responders, and Chase Products Co. conducts tabletop and hands-on emergency response drills annually.  In addition, the plan is reviewed at least annually and is amended as necessary.  Some of the response actions are coordinated with the Broadview Fire Department and the LaGrange Park Fire Department.

Planned changes to improve safety at the facility include continued training of employees on the emergency response contingency plan.
